# Draft:Holocaust Awareness Museum and Education Center

}}
The Holocaust Awareness Museum and Education Center (HAMEC) is a Holocaust museum in Elkins Park, Pennsylvania.
Overview
HAMEC's museum space contains nearly 150 artifacts related to the Holocaust, including passports survivors used to flee Nazi-occupied territories, cremation urns from Dachau, and examples of Nazi propaganda books, like "The Poisonous Mushroom" and "Trust No Fox in the Green Meadow and No Jew on His Oath."
HAMEC's collection is available as an online database, along with more than a dozen originally-produced testimonies the museum recorded with Holocaust survivors.
HAMEC hosts concerts for youth choirs to perform for members of the community and Holocaust survivors.
Outside of its museum space, HAMEC offers classroom programming for Philadelphia-area schools, where Holocaust survivors share their stories.
During the 2019-20 school year, HAMEC programming reached more than 23,000 students and adults in the Philadelphia area. HAMEC also exhibits Holocaust-related art and artifacts during some of its school visits.
History
HAMEC was founded in 1961 by Yaakov Riz, a Holocaust survivor who lost 83 members of his family in concentration camps.
The museum was originally located in Riz' basement in Northeast Philadelphia but has grown into larger venues over time. Since 2020, it has occupied a floor of Reform Congregation Keneseth Israel in Elkins Park.
